Situation1: They openly turn to each other for help in a difficult personal moment.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: The nun has a quiet afternoon and plans to spend time in personal spiritual reading and contemplation.
Story: I sat in my small room at the convent, sunlight slanting across the pages of the scripture I had planned to study all afternoon. The quiet was a rare gift, and I felt a deep longing to lose myself in prayer and reflection, to nourish my spirit as my vows required. Just as I settled in, my phone buzzed. It was my younger sister, her name lighting up the screen. I hesitated, knowing she wouldn’t call unless she truly needed me. We’d always promised to support each other, to be there in moments of crisis. My heart twisted as I imagined her alone, perhaps crying, reaching out for comfort only I could give. Yet, I also felt the weight of my commitment to this sacred time, the expectation that I devote myself fully to spiritual growth. The silence around me grew heavy, filled with the tension between my devotion as a nun and my love as a sister. I stared at the phone, torn, feeling the pull of both worlds and the ache of not knowing which to choose.
